s.text: And for now the only practical way to enforce health standards on the product is to enforce sanitary standards on its production.
Here's the story: Last spring, there was an outbreak of a nasty disease known as cyclosporiasis, which was eventually traced to Guatemalan raspberries.
Here's the story: Last spring, there was an outbreak of a nasty disease known as cyclosporiasis, which was eventually traced to Guatemalan raspberries.
Here's the story: Last spring, there was an outbreak of a nasty disease known as cyclosporiasis, which was eventually traced to Guatemalan raspberries.

The demands for protection would not abate because for the U.S. industry competing against imports, it doesn't matter how the clothing was produced . When the U.S. consumer is offered cheaper shirts from abroad, the United States loses the same number of shirt-making jobs regardless of whether the shirts were produced by workers making 30 cents an hour or $30 an hour.
And manufactured exports, initially based on low wages, are the only route we know for rapid economic development.
And so the supposed friends of poor workers abroad are no friends at all.
If they got their way the result for the poor Freedonian would not just be no sweatshop--it would be no job.
